data.q: Which Node.js module is primarily used to create HTTP servers?
data.explanation: The 'http' module in Node.js provides the functionality to create HTTP servers and clients.

data.q: What is the default port number for HTTP servers?
data.explanation: Port 80 is the default port for HTTP servers, while 443 is the default for HTTPS.

data.q: Which method of the http.ServerResponse object is used to send data back to the client?
data.explanation: The 'write()' method is used to send data chunks to the client before ending the response.

data.q: What does the 'end()' method of http.ServerResponse do?
data.explanation: The 'end()' method signals that the response is complete and no more data will be sent.

data.q: Which property of the IncomingMessage object contains the HTTP request headers?
data.explanation: The 'headers' property of IncomingMessage stores all the HTTP request headers.

data.q: How can you parse the URL of an incoming HTTP request in Node.js?
data.explanation: The 'url' module provides the 'url.parse()' method to parse request URLs.

data.q: Which status code represents 'Not Found' in HTTP?
data.explanation: HTTP status code 404 indicates that the requested resource could not be found.

data.q: What is the purpose of the 'Content-Type' header in HTTP responses?
o: Specifies the size of the content
Specifies the type of the content being sent
Specifies the encoding of the connection
data.explanation: The 'Content-Type' header tells the client the media type of the resource, such as text/html or application/json.

data.q: Which Node.js module is used to handle secure HTTPS connections?
data.explanation: The 'https' module is a variant of the 'http' module that supports SSL/TLS for secure communication.

data.q: What does the HTTP status code 500 represent?
data.explanation: Status code 500 indicates an Internal Server Error, meaning something went wrong on the server side.
